Hello.
I am working on something similar, and have written C++14 code to ge=
nerate mazes for my ES HyperNEAT work.
You are welcome to use my code in yo=
ur project if you like.
flajann2/rubyneat_examples

| =C2=A0 |  =

Fred Mitchell,=C2=A0


+49 (0)15 259 409475, Skype: fla=
jann
 


     On Monday, 13 July 2015, 0:21, "sjoshi181@... [neat]" <=
neat@yahoogroups.com> wrote:
   

 =C2=A0   Hey, I'm playing around with hy=
perNEAT, and I want to evolve more complex behaviors than what we have so f=
ar. Currently I want an AI that can navigate 2d mazes, and makes complex as=
sociations that you can query for. What I want specifically is an AI that c=
an learn to navigate an arbitrary maze and start and goal points, understan=
ds where it has been, and all unexplored paths. Then you should be able to =
ask the AI things like the shortest path back to the start point based on w=
here it has traveled, how many unexplored forks did it see. It should be ab=
le to do that for randomly generated mazes. This is a small step towards a =
much more complex AI that I have in mind.
I've implemented a basic version =
of hyperNEAT, and played around with it. I've learned some very important t=
hings along the way. You need to be very careful about the training environ=
ment, make it too complex, and everything might die off, make it to simple,=
 you might not get the behavior you want. The method I'm going with is incr=
emental environments. Start off with simple environments, then gradually ma=
ke them more complex, requiring more complex behaviors to form. I also thin=
k that the standard artificial neural networks are powerful enough for what=
 I want. The biological analogy is that evolution is plastic to its environ=
ment, and the environment constantly changes. The evolution of our eyes hap=
pened in many different environment in our evolutionary history and thus in=
 many incremental steps, each transitional phase suited for different envir=
onments/use.=C2=A0
=C2=A0I need the network to some how interact with long =
term memory. I've looked at neural turing machines from Google and memory n=
etworks from Facebook, but I'm not satisfied with those approaches. The thi=
ngs we are evolving are already programs, we can give them all kinds of pow=
erful tools, and we just need to provide it with 'neural hooks' to allow it=
 to start utilizing them (my philosophy is that we as humans used paper, pe=
ncil and a slide rule to do complex calculations that put a man on the moon=
. Why can't we give neural networks tools to aid their cognition the same w=
ay humans do?). They use complex structures because they need to be able to=
 train them using gradient decent based algorithms, but evolutionary algori=
thms don't have that requirement (initially they might not be able to prope=
rly utilize the tools, but slowly they will begin to. Again, I think you ne=
ed to evolve it in incremental steps, and have to be very clever about your=
 environments). =C2=A0
In terms of what kind of neurons I want to evolve, I=
've taken a few courses on coursera on neuroscience and cognition, and ther=
e are some structures that I am very fascinated by. =C2=A0This is a video o=
f the basal ganglia which is responsible for you motor movement.=C2=A0Khan =
Academy - The Basal Ganglia: The Direct PathwayThe basal ganglia is a very =
dynamic system with many intricate pathways interacting with different part=
s of the brain. I want take inspiration from this and have a description of=
 a genone that can encode and mutate sections and pathway interactions. 
| =
   |
|    |        |    |       Khan Academy - The Basal Ganglia: The Direc=
t Pat...  An overview of the direct pathway of movement, a pathway in the b=
rain that allows us to make voluntary movements and is controlled by th... =
   |    |
|      View on www.youtube.com         |    Preview by Yahoo    |=

iv id=3D"yiv8402357930ygrp-text">
      
      
      <div></div><div><span=
>Hey, I'm playing around with hyperNEAT, and I want to evolve more complex =
behaviors than what we have so far. Currently I want an AI that can navigat=
e 2d mazes, and makes complex associations that you can query for. What I w=
ant specifically is an AI that can learn to navigate an arbitrary maze and =
start and goal points, understands where it has been, and all unexplored pa=
ths. Then you should be able to ask the AI things like the shortest path ba=
ck to the start point based on where it has traveled, how many unexplored f=
orks did it see. It should be able to do that for randomly generated mazes.=
 This is a small step towards a much more complex AI that I have in mind.</=
span></div><div><br clear=3D"none"></div><div>I've implemented a basic vers=
ion of hyperNEAT, and played around with it. I've learned some very importa=
nt things along the way. You need to be very careful about the training env=
ironment, make it too complex, and everything might die off, make it to sim=
ple, you might not get the behavior you want. The method I'm going with is =
incremental environments. Start off with simple environments, then graduall=
y make them more complex, requiring more complex behaviors to form. I also =
think that the standard artificial neural networks are powerful enough for =
what I want. The biological analogy is that evolution is plastic to its env=
ironment, and the environment constantly changes. The evolution of our eyes=
 happened in many different environment in our evolutionary history and thu=
s in many incremental steps, each transitional phase suited for different e=
nvironments/use. </div><div><br clear=3D"none"></div><div> I need=
 the network to some how interact with long term memory. I've looked at neu=
ral turing machines from Google and memory networks from Facebook, but I'm =
not satisfied with those approaches. The things we are evolving are already=
 programs, we can give them all kinds of powerful tools, and we just need t=
o provide it with 'neural hooks' to allow it to start utilizing them (my ph=
ilosophy is that we as humans used paper, pencil and a slide rule to do com=
plex calculations that put a man on the moon. Why can't we give neural netw=
orks tools to aid their cognition the same way humans do?). They use comple=
x structures because they need to be able to train them using gradient dece=
nt based algorithms, but evolutionary algorithms don't have that requiremen=
t (initially they might not be able to properly utilize the tools, but slow=
ly they will begin to. Again, I think you need to evolve it in incremental =
steps, and have to be very clever about your environments).  </div><di=
v><span><br clear=3D"none"></span></div><div><span>In terms of what kind of=
 neurons I want to evolve, I've taken a few courses on coursera on neurosci=
ence and cognition, and there are some structures that I am very fascinated=
 by.  This is a video of the basal ganglia which is responsible for yo=
u motor movement. <a rel=3D"nofollow" shape=3D"rect" target=3D"_blank"=
 href=3D"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3DnoBTt1tsAMs">Khan Academy - The =
Basal Ganglia: The Direct Pathway</a></span></div><div>The basal ganglia is=
 a very dynamic system with many intricate pathways interacting with differ=
ent parts of the brain. I want take inspiration from this and have a descri=
ption of a genone that can encode and mutate sections and pathway interacti=
ons.</div><div class=3D"yiv8402357930link-enhancr-attachment yiv8402357930l=
ink-enhancr-element" id=3D"yiv8402357930enhancrCard_1" style=3D"width:450px=
